results.title: A Doll's house: by Henrik Ibsen
results.creator_credit: Patrick Garland, Hillard Elkins and Elkins Productions
results.brief_description: Ibsen’s feminist play set is Norway depicts Nora Helmer (Claire Bloom), a woman struggling for independence within her marriage, and against her husband’s will (played by Anthony Hopkins). In the face of male obstinacy and arrogance she sets off in search of her own life and destiny and breaks the shackles which have persisted in treating her as if she were a doll. Cast includes Denholm Elliot, Ralph Richardson and Edith Evans. Another version of Ibsens’s play, directed by Joseph Losey was released in the same year starring Jane Fonda and David Werner.

results.title: From India to Nepal
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

group_works.title: A Distant sound of bugles
group_works.creator_credit: Michael Pearce, Keith Adam, ABC and Royal Nepal Film Corporation

results.title: A Distant sound of bugles
results.creator_credit: Michael Pearce, Keith Adam, ABC and Royal Nepal Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “From India to Nepal”.
Siriparsad Guring returns to his Himalayan village after a 4-year term in a Gurkha regiment. He buys some land to farm and tries to settle back into village life with his wife and young child. After a few months he grows restless, realising that army service has alienated him from his former lifestyle. Narrated by John Gaden.

results.title: A Director talks about his film
results.creator_credit: David Grotenstein, Peter Riegert, Susan Krebs and Prospective Films
results.brief_description: A satirical film depicting an interview with an Italian film director, Aldo Altonandino who’s remarks in Italian are translated into English by a deadpanned, uninvolved female interpreter. As he gets carried away by his pseudo-eloquence the translator continues in robot-like fashion. As the camera pulls back, the real director appears explaining his idea for the film.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Grotenstein, Peter Riegert, Susan Krebs and Prospective Films

results.title: A Handful of dust
results.creator_credit: Charles Sturridge, Derek Granger, New Line Cinema and Stagescreen
results.brief_description: Tony and Brenda Last (James Wilby and Kristin Scott Thomas) appear to be the perfect married ccouple - with money, position, a great country house and an adored son, John Andrew. When Tony inadvertently invites John Beaver (Rupert Graves), an idle and penniless young socialite, to stay for the weekend, he sets in motion a series of events which drastically disrupts the course of all their lives. Brenda drifts into an affair with the worthless Mr. Beaver, with disastrous consequences, particularly for Tony, who remains unaware of Brenda’s betrayal until the tragic death of their young son. As Brenda leaves home to take up a precarious life with her lover in London. Tony sets sail with an eccentric explorer on an expedition to the South American rain forests. Lost in the jungle and stricken by fever, Tony is rescued from death by the eccentric Mr. Todd (Alec Guinness) with unexpected and sinister results.

results.title: A Great white bird
results.creator_credit: Michael McKennirey, Colin Low, Desmond Dew and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film documents the efforts of a group of people in Canada and the United States to sav the whooping crane from extinction. They display great determination and resourcefulness in their dealings with this mysterious, fiercely independent pre-Ice Age creature.

results.title: A Good Eye for Story
results.credit_line:
Filmed in Mbantua (Alice Springs)
Equipment provided by Panavision Australia
Colour by Matt Fezz
Special thanks to CAAMA Productions
results.material_description: Single-channel video, HDMI 4k video projection, 16:9, colour, sound, 3:06 min
results.brief_description: Dylan River’s film A Good Eye for Story is a quirky and intimate picture looking at the framework for which he shares his ideas and the impact that his family, community and the landscape around Alice Springs have had on his growing practice as a storyteller.

constellations_other.name: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls
constellations_other.description: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls explores the reality of living in Mparntwe (Alice Springs) through the eyes of the artists, who grew up there. Place and Indigenous representation are also vital to the other works in this Constellation.

results.headline_credit_for_label:
filmed in Mbantua (Alice Springs)

Equipment provided by Panavision Australia

Colour by Matt Fezz
results.description:
Dylan River is a filmmaker who shares stories from his unique perspective as a Kaytetye man. River works across many roles including cinematography, directing, and writing, for web series, documentary, short film, and cinema.

River’s film A Good Eye for Story is a quirky and intimate picture looking at the framework for which he shares his ideas and the impact that his family, community and the landscape around Alice Springs have had on his growing practice as a storyteller.

“This film explores my journey over the past ten years of being behind the cinema camera. The way my eye has changed from looking at images as being formulaic to appreciating the story behind every one.” – Dylan River
description_for_label:
Dylan River is a filmmaker who shares stories from his unique perspective as a Kaytetye man. River works across many roles including cinematography, directing, and writing, for web series, documentary, short film, and cinema.

River’s film A Good Eye for Story is a quirky and intimate picture looking at the framework for which he shares his ideas and the impact that his family, community and the landscape around Alice Springs have had on his growing practice as a storyteller.

“This film explores my journey over the past ten years of being behind the cinema camera. The way my eye has changed from looking at images as being formulaic to appreciating the story behind every one.” – Dylan River

results.title: A Grain of sand
results.creator_credit: David Keith Hardy, John Luck and UNICEF
results.brief_description: Firstly children’s needs are dramatised through a poem by William Blake and drawings by Ronald Searle. Then we follow a 10 year old Tunisian Arab boy to a health clinic, a school and a vocational training centre - three concrete ways to help meet children’s needs.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Keith Hardy, John Luck and UNICEF

results.title: A Gift for Kate
results.creator_credit: John Smith, Barrie Howells, Robert Fortier, Sam Grana and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Kate is a recently discharged mental patient who now lives in a run-down halfway house. The weekly visits from her fifteen-year-old son, Arthur, are bright spots in her difficult life. For Arthur, who has trouble dealing with his mother’s condition, the visits are difficult. Arthur’s embarrassment and confusion lead him to lie to his girlfriend about Kate, with some surprising results when the two women meet.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Smith, Barrie Howells, Robert Fortier, Sam Grana and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: A Friend at the door
results.creator_credit: Leslie McFarlane, James Beveridge and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This is a story of how rural social workers in British Columbia cover a large and rugged province, and of the ways in which they help people in many kinds of trouble to solve their problems. Taking four cases - a pensioner, a youngster in juvenile court, an unmarried mother and a family distressed by the threat of illness and poverty - the film describes how each case is investigated, and how people in need are put in touch with available aid, both government and private.
